In DESeq2 package, dispersion can be analyzed using the `plotDispEsts()` function. This function creates a plot of the dispersion estimates for all genes in the dataset, which can help identify genes that have larger than expected dispersion. Here is an example of how to use the `plotDispEsts()` function:
```
library(DESeq2)

# Create a DESeqDataSet object
dds <- DESeqDataSetFromMatrix(countData = counts, colData = sample_data, design = ~ condition)

# Fit the model and estimate the dispersions
dds <- estimateSizeFactors(dds)
dds <- estimateDispersions(dds)

# Plot the dispersion estimates
plotDispEsts(dds)
```
This will create a plot of the dispersion estimates for all genes in the dataset. The x-axis represents the mean of the gene's counts, and the y-axis represents the dispersion estimate for that gene. The plot will show a line for the mean of the dispersion estimates and a grey ribbon representing the range of the dispersion estimates. If a gene has a dispersion estimate that is higher than the mean of the dispersion estimates, it is considered to have larger than expected dispersion.

You can also use the `plotDispEsts(dds, subset = "gene of interest")` to plot the dispersion estimate of a specific gene of interest.

It's worth noting that dispersion estimation is an important step in DESeq2, as it helps to identify genes whose expression levels may be more variable than expected, which can be a sign of technical variability or biological variability, the latter of which may be interesting.
